I am going to convert this to a discussion, nd close this.
For now. we don't have a good solution for above challenges.
According to the official response, https://github.com/alibaba/nacos/issues/9091#issuecomment-1237684980, this is not a CVE we need to concern.
`CI / Dependency licenses` skipped, have you checked this locally?

> `CI / Dependency licenses` skipped, have you checked this locally?

this is expected, I verified this locally.
Just also enabled the dependencies check when UI changed

> 

facing save issue on version skywalking:8.9.0
We replied this many many times. This is not supported.
Search issues before you submit a new one.
Agent plugins are contributed by community. We would not debug for you. You have to debug by yourself.

> Just also enabled the dependencies check when UI changed

Looks like the action cannot detect specific files changes in sub module, just change to if ui sub module changed trigger the workflow.
Make sense. Submodule is one file from git perspective.
@yswdqz How is your side work? Are things working as expected?

> @yswdqz How is your side work? Are things working as expected?

Everything is OK, I am writing the e2e. And I will sent the PR tomorrow.
Is it OK that I just set the slow statement there?

I get it.

But I think this feature was already supported after 3 years. I'm wrong.

> If this pull request closes/resolves/fixes an existing issue, replace the issue number. Closes https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/9548 .

I think we should not close issue, this is just pre-requires feature for that issue.
@yswdqz Could you share how the final LAL script would like? How could we know the logs about MySQL slow SQL reports? Have we successfully set the tags for logs?
Wait for @kezhenxu94 @wankai123 to review LAL design and details.

> @yswdqz Could you share how the final LAL script would like? How could we know the logs about MySQL slow SQL reports? Have we successfully set the tags for logs?

The LAL script are following:
```
rules:
  - name: mysql-slowsql
    dsl: |
      filter {
        json{
        }
        slowSql {
          serviceName parsed.service as String
          id parsed.id as String
          statement parsed.statement as String
          latency parsed.query_time as Long
          layer parsed.layer as String
          timeBucket parsed.time as Long
        }
      }
```
I think we don't need to know the log is about MySQL slow SQL reports. We just set the slowSql in LAL, and it can generate service and TopNStatement by the log, and save them into database. 

The json I send via http is following:
```
[{"date":1662478799.208541,"body":{"json":{"json":"{\"time\":\"20220906153959\",\"id\":\"cb92c1a5b-2691e-fb2f-457a-9c72a392d9ed\",\"service\":\"root[root]@[175.172.37.237]\",\"statement\":\"SET timestamp=1662478799;select sleep(2);\",\"layer\":\"MYSQL\",\"query_time\":2000}"}},"service":"root[root]@[175.172.37.237]"}]
```

Hi, why do you think `parsed.isSlowSql` is so called "hijack", `parsed` is the original log fields parsed from the text format by log parser (json/regexp/yaml, etc.), it's an intermedia variable and I don't think we should limit the fields.
Note: `parsed` is not what we use to persist in storage.
This is from the protocol definition perspective. We documented and exposed a log receiving protocol, but actually, users could push more fields than we defined.

> This is from the protocol definition perspective. We documented and exposed a log receiving protocol, but actually, users could push more fields than we defined.

Hi,

1. `parsed` is parsed from `LogDataBody body`. https://github.com/apache/skywalking-data-collect-protocol/blob/906a834dc0c3fb66719b8313f8f9298be3a27349/logging/Logging.proto#L63
2. The protocol never/cannot define what fields users can push, `body` is a raw text/json/yaml, you have no idea what can be in the raw text/json/yaml.
3. As I said, `parsed` is just an intermedia variable, it's not what we persist in storage. What we persist is the [`Log` Java bean](https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/526aa3a5fd077ce548eed8e78052eff394209847/oap-server/server-core/src/main/java/org/apache/skywalking/oap/server/core/source/Log.java), and its fields are defined.
4. Users must have an ability to hold an intermedia variable so that they know how to extract those fields into the `Log` instance and what to persist

The usage of `parsed.isSlowSql` is a correct use case in my opinion

I am totally fine user could add a new field in the parsed object. This is not what I felt was wrong.
The key point is a network protocol. We need to protect our services by not receiving data we don't expected and define. Once we limit that, the further process is open to user to define and add new fields according to their requirements.

> I am totally fine user could add a new field in the parsed object. This is not what I felt was wrong.
> The key point is a network protocol. We need to protect our services by not receiving data we don't expected and define. Once we limit that, the further process is open to user to define and add new fields according to their requirements.

Can you help, how we can limit what users can push here in the `LogDataBody body` field? It's a raw text https://github.com/apache/skywalking-data-collect-protocol/blob/906a834dc0c3fb66719b8313f8f9298be3a27349/logging/Logging.proto#L63

And I don't know why it makes sense to limit those, users logs can have unpredictable fields

Oh, I didn't realize this parsed is including the `body`. I was expecting `parsed.body.xxx` is for user extension.

This is an interesting bug, as we never have LAL used in this kind of complexity, This is a good and real scenario.

From my understanding, this status should be able to override through `sink` and `slowSQL` functions. It is true that the previous LAL declared it is aborted unless other LAL declare to persistent. Meanwhile, if this log has been declared `sink`, then other's `abort` should not be able to override as the log should be persistent as declared.

I want to confirm, is `slowSQL` declare the status? As slowSQL is just shipping the data into sources(OAL), the log should be `abort` as the final status.

If we want an accurate process, then every LAL script should run in a different context. The input and result should be kept and reset if we have concerned that a script received dirty logs(processed by the previous script) due to the multiple scripts case.

> As slowSQL is just shipping the data into sources(OAL), the log should be `abort` as the final status.

I think `slowsql` maybe should not abort logs. Because it is in extractor now ,and it will not modify the log data.
Maybe users will use other filters(such as `metrics` in `extractor`)  after use slowsql.

`abort` was designed to stop the whole process as soon as possible so there is no unnecessary further operations. For now I think the quick fix is to use `if (tag("LOG_KIND") == "MYSQL_SLOW_SQL") { // slow sql logic }` instead of `if not slow sql then abort`.
